_within_24_hours_of_thawing_of_the_injured_tissue.There_are_variable_dosing_regimens_and_institutional_protocols.Alteplase_may_be_given_with_simultaneous_parenteral_anticoagulation_(eg,_low-molecular-weight_heparin_or_an_unfractionated_heparin_infusion)._Alteplase_0.15_mg/kg_intravenous_bolus_over_15_minutes,_followed_by_0.15_mg/kg/hour_continuous_infusion_over_6_hours_(maximum:_100_mg)_orAlteplase_2-4_mg_intravenous_bolus_followed_by_a_0.5-1_mg/hour_continuous_intra-arterial_infusion_through_the_femoral_or_brachial_artery.Vasodilators/Prostacyclin_may_decrease_amputation_rates_for_grade_2+_presenting_within_48_hours_(eg,_Iloprost,_reserpine,_pentoxifylline,_buflomedil)Low-molecular-weight_dextran_may_be_beneficial_when_thrombolytics_are_not_indicated.When_local_specialists_are_not_immediately_available,_the_University_of_Utah_Frostbite_hotline_may_provide_assistance_(801-581-2700).PITFALLSAvoid_heparin,_as_there_is_no_evidence_to_support_its_use_(except_with_thrombolytics).

For_minor_conditions_related_to_heat:Prickly_heat_(miliaria_rubra,_lichen_tropicus):_Wear_loose-fitting_clothing_and_avoid_sweating._Antihistamines,_steroid_cream,_and_calamine_lotion_can_relieve_itching._Chlorhexidine_antibacterial_washes_can_also_be_effective.Heat_edema:_Compression_stockings_and_lower_extremity_elevation_are_the_treatments_of_choice._Diuretics_are_not_effective_and_can_compound_other_heat-stress-associated_issues,_including_hypovolemia_and_electrolyte_abnormalities._Heat_edema_usually_resolves_without_treatment_within_several_days.Heat_cramps:_Minimize_exertion_and_replace_fluids_and_salt_orally.Heat_syncope:_Remove_from_heat_and_cease_exertion._Perform_oral_rehydration.For_heat_exhaustion:Remove_from_the_hot_environment_and_minimize_exertion.Perform_hydration,_either_orally_or_intravenously.Although_rarely_necessary,_cooling_measures_can_be_considered.For_heat_stroke:Early_recognition_is_key_to_effective_treatment.Cooling_measures_should_be_initiated_immediately_in_suspected_cases_of_heat_illness_and_should_not_be_delayed_while_the_workup_progresses.In_a_hyperthermic_patient_with_altered_sensorium,_heat_stroke_should_be_assumed_as_the_core_temperature_can_continue_to_rise._Cooling_should_not_be_delayed_even_if_the_patient?s_temperature_is_below_40Ã¸C.PEARLSRemove_the_patient_from_the_hot_environment_and_minimize_exertion.The_patient?s_clothing_should_be_removed_prior_to_cooling.Rapid_cooling_is_vital_in_the_management_of_heat_stroke_to_minimize_heat_injury_and_maximize_the_patient_outcome;_it_should_therefore_be_initiated_as_early_as_possible.Conductive/immersion_cooling_via_cold_water_(1-17Ã¸C)_immersion_is_the_most_rapid,_effective,_and_preferred_cooling_method_in_all_cases_of_heat_stroke;_however,_it_can_be_impractical_or_difficult_depending_on_the_setting._It_is_also_used_for_classic_heat_stroke_cases_in_mass_gatherings,_such_as_concerts.PERSPECTIVESEvaporative_cooling_is_acceptable_in_hospital_settings_where_cold_water_immersion_is_not_feasible._This_method_involves_spraying_an_unclothed,_uncovered_patient_with_water_before_directing_air_from_fans_toward_the_patient_to_encourage_evaporation.Cold_intravenous_fluids,_cooling_blankets,_and_ice_packs_can_be_used_as_supplemental_cooling_techniques;_however,_these_are_minimally_effective_on_their_own.In_the_prehospital_setting,_the_application_of_cold_packs_to_the_cheeks,_palms,_and_soles_may_be_more_effective_than_application_to_the_neck,_groin,_and_axillae.PEARLSContinue_cooling_until_a_core_temperature_of_38Ã¸C_(100.4Ã¸F)_has_been_reached.There_is_some_discrepancy_regarding_the_optimal_target_temperature_at_which_to_end_cooling._The_consensus_for_evaporative_cooling_is_to_aim_for_38Ã¸C_(100.4Ã¸F),_whereas_for_conductive/immersion_cooling,_the_target_is_39Ã¸C_(102.2Ã¸F).PITFALLSThere_is_no_role_for_antipyretics_or_dantrolene_in_the_treatment_of_heat_stroke.Treat_the_signs_and_symptoms_of_shock_with_usual_supportive_care.Consider_the_early_administration_of_antibiotics_if_the_etiology_remains_unclear_and_infection_is_still_suspected.

Apply_well-aimed_and_focused_direct_pressure_to_any_bleeding_wounds._Apply_tourniquet_and/or_wound_packing_if_bleeding_is_extensive_or_appears_life-threatening.After_hemostasis_is_achieved,_wounds_should_be_evaluated_and_examined_closely_to_identify_injuries_to_underlying_structures.PEARLSFollowing_local_anesthesia,_debride_wounds,_remove_devitalized_tissue,_and_irrigate_with_copious_fluids.There_is_no_benefit_to_using_0.9%_sodium_chloride;_potable_tap_water_has_been_shown_to_be_equivalent_to_sterile_fluids_in_numerous_studies.Patients_with_an_immunocompromised_state,_especially_asplenia,_chronic_alcohol_abuse,_diabetes,_and_peripheral_vascular_disease_are_at_highest_risk_of_infection.There_should_be_a_low_threshold_for_the_use_of_prophylactic_antibiotics_in_immunocompromised_patients.Immunocompromised_patients,_especially_those_with_asplenia,_are_at_increased_risk_for_infection_from_Capnocytophaga_canimorsus,_a_pathogen_found_in_dog_and_cat_saliva_that_has_low_virulence_and_rarely_causes_infection_in_healthy_patients._C._canimorsus_causes_rapid_development_of_sepsis,_meningitis,_gangrene,_and_bacteremia,_and_is_sensitive_to_standard_antimicrobials_used_for_treatment_of_soft_tissue_infections_from_mammalian_bites.Rabies_prophylaxis:Consult_the_local_health_department_and/or_the_Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention_(CDC)_for_any_animal_bites_if_there_is_a_concern_of_possible_rabies_or_need_for_rabies_post-exposure_prophylaxis;_eg,_rabies_immune_globulin_and_rabies_vaccine.Raccoons,_skunks,_and_foxes_are_the_terrestrial_animals_most_often_infected_with_rabies_in_the_United_States._All_bites_by_such_wildlife_must_be_considered_a_possible_exposure_to_the_rabies_virus.Bats_are_the_leading_cause_of_rabies_deaths_in_people_in_the_United_States._Rabies_can_spread_to_people_from_bats_after_minor,_seemingly_unimportant,_or_unrecognized_bites_or_scratches._Rabies_post-exposure_prophylaxis,_which_includes_vaccination,_is_recommended_for_any_person_with_a_bite_or_scratch_from_a_bat,_unless_the_bat_is_available_for_testing_and_tests_negative_for_rabies.If_the_biting_cat,_dog,_or_ferret_appeared_healthy_when_the_patient_was_bitten,_it_can_be_confined_by_its_owner_for_10_days_and_observed._No_anti-rabies_prophylaxis_is_needed._No_person_in_the_United_States_has_ever_contracted_rabies_from_a_dog,_cat,_or_ferret_held_in_quarantine_for_10_days.If_there_is_concern_for_the_animal_being_rabid,_immediate_post-exposure_prophylaxis_is_indicated.If_the_animal_is_not_available_for_quarantine_and_there_is_low_clinical_suspicion_of_the_animal_having_rabies,_consult_the_local_public_health_department_and/or_the_CDC.Summary_of_the_CDC_Recommendations_for_Rabies_ProphylaxisBefore_considering_or_administering_rabies_immune_globulin_and_rabies_vaccine_following_bites_from_lagomorphs_(eg,_rabbits,_hares)_and_small_rodents_(eg,_squirrels,_hamsters,_guinea_pigs,_gerbils,_chipmunks,_rats,_and_mice),_we_recommend_consulting_the_local_health_department_and/or_the_CDC_as_these_small_animals_are_not_reported_to_transmit_rabies_to_humans,_and_patients_almost_never_require_post-exposure_prophylaxis.Guidelines_for_primary_closure_versus_leaving_a_wound_open_are_controversial_and_data_are_mixed.PERSPECTIVESGenerally,_it_is_considered_standard_practice_to_close_wounds_where_cosmetic_outcome_is_important;_eg,_on_the_face;_however,_due_to_concern_for_increased_risk_of_infection,_shared_decision-making_is_recommended_when_discussing_wound_closure.PEARLSInfection_prophylaxis_is_recommended_forDog_bites_to_the_handsAll_human_and_cat_bitesAny_patient_at_high_risk_for_infectionGeneral_recommendations_for_prophylactic_antibiotic_regimen_include_3_to_5_days_of_one_of_the_following_antibiotics:Amoxicillin-clavulanate_potassium_875/125_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hoursIf_patient_is_allergic_to_penicillin,_metronidazole_500_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hours_plus_doxycycline_100_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hours_orTrimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole_(160_mg/800_mg)_plus_metronidazole_500_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hours_orCiprofloxacin_500_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hoursIn_any_bite_wound_that_presents_with_infection,_administer_antimicrobials_that_cover_the_common_pathogens_(oral_flora,_gram-negatives)._A_7-_to_14-day_course_of_the_above-recommended_antibiotics_is_sufficient_for_superficial_infections,_but_severe_infections_may_warrant_intravenous_antibiotics_and_surgical_consultation.Non-human_primate_bite_post-exposure_prophylaxis:Current_recommendations_from_the_CDC_are_that_14_days_of_post-exposure_prophylaxis_should_be_given_to_any_patient_who_had_contact_(nonintact_skin_or_mucous_membranes)_with_potentially_infectious_macaque_body_fluids,_within_5_days_of_the_exposure.Valacyclovir_1_g_by_mouth_every_8_hours_(drug_of_choice)_orAcyclovir_800_mg_by_mouth_5_times_per_day.Treatment_of_infectionPatients_who_present_with_infection_should_receive_treatment_tailored_to_the_location,_severity,_and_risk_profile_of_the_patient.Patients_with_severe_infections_may_benefit_from_parenteral_antibiotics.This_includes_patients_with_signs_of_systemic_toxicity_or_sepsis,_rapidly_spreading_infections,_progression_of_infection_despite_oral_antibiotics,_inability_to_tolerate_oral_agents,_deep_infections_involving_bones,_joints,_and/or_tendons,_or_necrotizing_infections.Recommended_agents_includeAmpicillin-sulbactam_3_g_intravenously_every_6_hours_for_7-14_days_orPiperacillin-tazobactam_3.375_g_intravenously_every_6_hours_for_7-10_days_orThird-generation_cephalosporinCeftriaxone_1_g_intravenously_every_24_hours_for_7-14_days_plusMetronidazole_500_mg_intravenously_every_8_hours_for_7-10_days_for_anaerobic_coverage_orCeftriaxone_1_g_intravenously_every_24_hours_for_7-14_days_plusClindamycin_900_mg_intravenously_every_8_hours_for_7-10_days_for_anaerobic_coverage.Tetanus_prophylaxis._If_uncertain_whether_the_patient_has_completed_a_primary_series_or_if_it_is_more_than_5_years_since_the_last_booster,_give_tetanus-diphtheria-acellular_pertussis_(Tdap)_0.5_mL_intramuscular_booster._If_the_wound_is_tetanus-prone,_give_tetanus_immune_globulin_in_addition_to_Tdap.

PITFALLSFor_moribund_patients_pulled_from_water,_the_differential_diagnosis_also_includes_submersion_injury,_diving_injury,_hypothermia,_and_trauma._Consider_concomitant_medical_etiologies_including_syncope_or_seizureWhen_no_antivenom_is_available,_provide_supportive_care.Do_not_attempt_venom_suction.Remove_any_accessible_spines/tentacles_with_forceps_(as_close_to_the_base_as_possible).Monitor_for_compartment_syndrome.Avoid_the_use_of_pressure_bandages_(except_in_cases_of_blue-ringed_octopus_envenomation).Apply_copious_irrigation_and_wound_care.First_aid_includes_the_application_of_vinegar,_hot_water,_or_the_use_of_regional_blocks.Deactivate_nematocysts_with_100%_acetic_acid_(vinegar).Pluck_off_the_tentacles/nematocysts_if_present_(use_an_instrument_or_glove_to_prevent_rescuer_exposure).Pain_control:Use_hot_water_(45Ã¸C_or_as_hot_as_tolerable)_for_pain_control_(exception:_sea_snakes).Use_a_shower_or_a_standard_cooler.Submerge_both_the_affected_limb_and_the_unaffected_limb_to_ensure_tolerability_and_prevent_burns.Utilize_regional_blocksBeware_of_the_fact_that_regional_blocks_+_hot_water_can_increase_the_risk_of_thermal_burns.Administer_intravenous_opioids_for_refractory_pain.Apply_topical_antihistamines_and_steroids_for_local_hypersensitivity_reactions.Consider_prophylactic_antibiotics_for_extensive_lacerations_or_deep_puncture_wounds.

Mobilization_of_extracorporeal_life_support_(ECLS)_resources_should_begin_early_for_hypothermic_patients_with_the_following:Temperature_less_than_28Ã¸C_(82Ã¸F)_(severe)No_vital_signsSystolic_BP_(SBP)_<90_mm_HgVentricular_arrhythmiasNo_contraindications_to_resuscitation_(See:_Contraindications_to_Resuscitation)In_temperatures_less_than_35Ã¸C_(95Ã¸F)_(mild_or_colder),_initiate_passive_rewarming.Remove_cold/wet_clothing.Provide_oral_glucose_when_appropriate_to_support_shivering.Insulate,_preferably_with_warm_blankets.If_intravenous_fluids_are_indicated,_use_warmed_fluids._Rapid_transfusion_devices_usually_have_fluid_warmers_and_may_be_more_readily_available_than_dedicated_fluid_warming_devices.In_temperatures_less_than_32Ã¸C_(89Ã¸F)_(moderate_or_colder),_use_active_external_rewarming.Perform_the_mild_hypothermia_interventions_above_AND_the_following:Administer_intravenous_fluids_via_a_warming_circuit_(plate_warmer,_Level_1_Hotline/Ranger/Thermal_Angel,_etc.)._Central_administration_of_42Ã¸C_(107Ã¸F)_fluids_is_best.If_no_warmer_is_available_and_institutional_protocols_allow,_1L_intravenous_fluid_bags_should_be_microwaved_at_high_power_(900_W_preferred)_for_2_minutes_and_shaken_to_mix_before_administration.Blood,_if_needed,_should_not_be_heated_to_a_temperature_greater_than_38Ã¸C_(100.4Ã¸F).Apply_active_external_rewarming_devices_such_as_forced_air_blankets_(eg,_Bair_Hugger),_water_circulation_pads_(eg,_Arctic_Sun),_radiant_heat_lamps,_hot_packs,_or_hot_blankets_as_available.If_unavailable,_heated_water_bottles_or_bags_of_intravenous_fluid_may_be_packed_into_junctional_regions_such_as_the_groin,_neck,_and_axilla.Warm_the_core_prior_to_extremities_for_moderate_or_severe_cases.In_mechanically_ventilated_patients,_use_100%_humidification_and_a_circuit_heater_set_to_40-45Ã¸C_(104-113Ã¸F).In_spontaneously_breathing_patients,_heated_humidification_may_be_provided_via_a_continuous_positive_airway_pressure_(CPAP)_circuit_or_vent_circuit_utilizing_a_CPAP_mask_and_CPAP_settings_(pressure_support_ventilation_with_CPAP_only).In_temperatures_less_than_28Ã¸C_(82Ã¸F)_(moderate_or_colder)_for_patients_who_remain_hemodynamically_stable,_use_minimally_invasive_rewarming.Perform_the_mild_and_moderate_hypothermia_interventions_AND_the_following:Use_intravascular_rewarming_catheters_such_as_the_Alsius/Zoll_ICY_catheters,_which_are_commonly_used_for_post-arrest_therapeutic_temperature_management.Avoid_physical_perturbations_that_may_precipitate_ventricular_arrhythmias.Consider_airway_protection_as_indicated.Place_an_esophageal_temperature_probe_in_intubated_patients.Place_a_3-way_urinary_catheter_for_continuous_irrigation_of_42Ã¸C_(107Ã¸F)_fluids.Alternatively,_use_a_single_lumen_foley_for_300_mL_?dwells,?_changed_every_15_minutes_(or_when_fluid_temperature_drops_significantly_if_using_a_temperature-sensing_urinary_catheter).When_using_bladder_warming,_if_using_a_temperature-sensing_urinary_catheter,_inform_the_patient_care_team_to_only_use_it_to_monitor_the_warming_fluid_temperature,_not_the_patient?s_core_body_temperature.In_temperatures_less_than_28Ã¸C_(82Ã¸F)_(severe_or_colder)_or_with_hemodynamic_instability_or_cardiac_arrest,_use_invasive_core_rewarming.Perform_all_of_the_above_PLUS:Perform_advanced_cardiac_life_support_(ACLS)._If_the_patient_has_a_pulse,_establish_ACLS_resources_at_the_bedside_to_prepare_for_imminent_arrest/ventricular_arrhythmia._Modify_ACLS_as_below:Recruit_multiple_compressors_or_use_mechanical_CPR_devices_with_extra_battery_packs.If_less_than_30Ã¸C_(85Ã¸F):_administer_one_dose_of_1_mg_intravenous_epinephrine_and_one_120-200_J_defibrillation_at_onset._Above_a_temperature_of_30Ã¸C_(85Ã¸F),_may_use_normal_ACLS_protocol_but_with_twice_as_much_time_between_doses/shocks._Greater_than_35Ã¸C,_resume_normal_ACLS.If_intubation_induction/paralytics_are_needed,_consider_a_half-dose_for_patients_with_temperatures_less_than_30Ã¸C_(85Ã¸F)_because_the_duration_of_the_agents_will_be_prolonged._Additionally,_expect_a_delayed_onset_of_the_agents_used.Spend_30-45_seconds_on_pulse_checks,_as_patients_often_have_profound_bradycardia._Alternatively,_assess_cardiac_activity_via_point-of-care_echocardiography_and_consider_ultrasound_pulse_check.Consider_contraindications._(See:_Contraindications_to_Resuscitation.)With_or_without_a_pulse,_activate_extracorporeal_life_support_(ECLS)._Rewarming_is_the_definitive_treatment_and_ECLS_is_the_best_definitive_method_of_rewarming._Unstable_patients_with_a_pulse_have_a_high_rate_of_arrest,_and_hypothermic_arrests_have_improved_outcomes_when_treated_at_an_ECLS_center.Alternatives_to_extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation_(ECMO)_include_traditional_cardiopulmonary_bypass_circuits_or_a_hemodialysis_circuit.When_ECLS_is_not_available_or_the_time_to_initiate_ECLS_treatment_is_prolonged,_rewarm_via_cavity_lavage_with_warm_fluids._Thoracic_lavage_provides_the_most_rapid_rewarming._(See:_Invasive_Rewarming)PITFALLSIf_central_venous_access_is_required,_keep_high_lines_in_distal_central_circulation_to_avoid_provoking_irritable_myocardium;_use_femoral_access_cautiously_if_ECLS_cannulation_is_anticipated._Avoid_transvenous_pacing,_which_may_precipitate_ventricular_dysrhythmias.

PEARLSMedical_stabilization_comes_first._Do_not_delay_stabilization_to_decontaminate_a_patient.Initiate_treatment_in_critically_ill_patients_as_noted_in_Approach_to_the_Critical_Patient._Resuscitation_measures_are_the_same_as_in_a_patient_not_exposed_to_radiation.Decontamination_can_commence_once_life-_or_limb-threatening_issues_have_been_addressed.External_decontamination:Remove_and_properly_bag_all_clothing.Cover_all_open_wounds_with_bio-occlusive_dressings_prior_to_decontamination_to_prevent_cross-contamination.Externally_decontaminate_with_soap_and_warm_water._Do_not_allow_the_water_to_run_into_orifices_or_open_wounds.Rinse_the_mouth_with_water;_however,_do_not_allow_the_patient_to_swallow;_have_them_spit_into_a_container.Gently_irrigate_any_wounds_with_isotonic_fluids.Place_absorbent_dressings_around_the_wound(s)_during_irrigation_to_prevent_run-off_and_cross-contamination.Internal_decontamination:_Whole-bowel_irrigation_or_chelation,_only_in_consultation_with_an_expert.Administer_antiemetics,_preferably_ondansetron,_for_nausea_and_vomiting.Administer_loperamide_for_diarrhea.PERSPECTIVESUnless_there_is_a_specific_medical_indication,_avoid_systemic_corticosteroids_as_there_is_a_lack_of_data_supporting_benefit.Depending_on_concern_for_the_degree_of_radiation_exposure_in_patients_still_in_the_prodromal_or_latent_phases,_initiate_early_prophylactic_antibiotics_(usually_a_fluoroquinolone)_or_cytokines_such_as_granulocyte_colony-stimulating_factor._These_should_be_administered_in_consultation_with_an_expert,_such_as_a_hospital?s_radiation_safety_officer,_a_medical_toxicologist,_or_someone_from_the_Radiation_Emergency_Assistance_Center/Teaching_Site_(REAC/TS).Administration_of_potassium_iodide,_a_form_of_iodine_that_is_not_radioactive,_may_be_recommended_following_exposure_to_radiation_(eg,_radioactive_iodine_[I-131])_to_decrease_the_absorption_of_radioactive_iodine_by_the_thyroid.The_Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention_has_information_on_pota Treatment_depends_on_the_etiology.Acute_suppurative_(bacterial)_parotitisIf_patient_is_well_appearing,_immunocompetent,_and_able_to_tolerate_oral_intake,_treat_with_one_of_the_following:MonotherapyAmoxicillin-clavulanate_875_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hoursPolydrug_regimens:Regimen_1Clindamycin_300-450_mg_by_mouth_every_8_hoursCiprofloxacin_500_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hoursRegimen_2Linezolid_600_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hoursMoxifloxacin_400_mg_by_mouth_every_24_hoursIf_a_patient_is_systemically_ill_or_unable_to_tolerate_oral_antibiotics,_administer_an_intravenous_crystalloid_bolus_and_treat_with_antibiotics.For_immunocompetent_and_community-acquired_infections_treat_with_one_of_the_following:MonotherapyAmpicillin-sulbactam_3_g_intravenous_every_6_hoursPolydrug_regimenCefuroxime_1.5_g_intravenous_every_8_hoursMetronidazole_500_mg_intravenous_every_8_hoursIf_there_is_concern_for_methicillin-resistant_Staphylococcus_aureus,_add_one_of_the_following:Clindamycin_900_mg_intravenous_every_8_hoursLinezolid_600_mg_intravenous_every_12_hoursVancomycin_loading_dose_of_25-30_mg/kg_intravenous_followed_by_15-20_mg/kg_intravenous_every_8_to_12_hoursFor_immunocompromised_or_hospital-acquired_infections,_treat_with_one_of_the_following_regimens:Regimen_1Vancomycin_loading_dose_of_25-30_mg/kg_intravenous_followed_by_15-20_mg/kg_intravenous_every_8_to_12_hoursCefepime_2_g_intravenous_every_12_hoursMetronidazole_500_mg_intravenous_every_8_hoursRegimen_2Linezolid_600_mg_intravenous_every_12_hoursPiperacillin-tazobactam_4.5_g_intravenous_every_6_hoursStandard_duration_of_treatment_is_10-14_days.Consult_otorhinolaryngology_(ear,_nose,_and_throat).Viral_parotitisTreatment_is_primarily_supportive.Antipyretics_and_analgesicsAcetaminophen_650-1000_mg_by_mouth_every_6_hours_as_neededIbuprofen_600_mg_by_mouth_every_6_to_8_hours_as_neededPain_not_responding_to_the_above_may_require_opioid_analgesics.Autoimmune_parotitisAntibiotics_should_be_administered_only_if_conco PITFALLSIf_viral_pharyngitis_is_suspected,_it_should_not_be_treated_with_antibiotics.Acetaminophen_or_a_nonsteroidal_anti-inflammatory_drug_(NSAID)_(eg,_ibuprofen)_can_be_used_as_adjunctive_treatment_for_pain_or_fever.Corticosteroids_(eg,_dexamethasone)_provide_symptomatic_relief_and_reduce_the_duration_of_symptoms.DexamethasoneAdults:_6-10_mg_intravenous_as_a_one-time_doseChildren:_0.6_mg/kg_by_mouth_as_a_one-time_dose_(maximum_single_dose:_10_mg)Treatment_for_gonococcal_pharyngitis_is_as_follows:Gonococcal_pharyngitis_requires_antibiotic_treatment.Ceftriaxone_500_mg_intramuscular_as_a_single_dose_(1_g_intramuscular_as_a_single_dose_for_persons_weighing_>150_kg)Treatment_for_infectious_mononucleosis_is_as_follows:EBV-associated_mononucleosis_is_generally_a_self-limited_disease.Treat_symptoms_with_analgesics_and_antipyretics_(acetaminophen_and_non-steroidal_anti-inflammatories).Routine_use_of_steroids_is_not_recommended_but_may_be_considered_if_there_is_concern_for_impending_airway_obstruction_(single_dose_of_dexamethasone_0.6mg/kg_by_mouth_once).PEARLSAdvise_against_strenuous_exercise_for_3_weeks_and_contact_sports_for_4-6_weeks_from_symptom_onset_to_reduce_the_risk_of_splenic_rupture.Advise_the_patient_against_kissing_or_sharing_food_and_drinks_to_reduce_the_risk_of_virus_transmission_through_their_saliva.Treatment_for_group_A_?-hemolytic_Streptococcus_is_as_follows:Typically_self-resolves,_even_in_the_absence_of_antimicrobial_treatment,_although_antibiotics_may_reduce_the_duration_of_illness_and_are_often_prescribed_to_decrease_the_risk_of_suppurative_complications_and_acute_rheumatic_fever.Choose_one_of_the_following_antibiotics:Penicillin_VKAdult_dose500_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hours_for_10_daysPediatric_dose_(based_on_weight)Weight_Ã³27_kg:_250_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hours_for_10_daysWeight_>27_kg:_500_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hours_for_10_daysAmoxicillinAdult_dose500_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hours_for_10_days_or1,000_mg_by_mouth_every_24_hours_for_10_daysPediatric_dose_(based_on_age)<3_years_old:_25_mg/kg/dose_by_mouth_every_12_hours_for_10_days_(maximum_dose:_500_mg)Ã²3_years_old:_50_mg/kg_by_mouth_every_24_hours_for_10_days_(maximum_dose:_1,000_mg)_or_25_mg/kg_every_12_hours_for_10_days_(maximum_dose:_500_mg)Penicillin_G_benzathineAdult_doseGive_1.2_million_units_(benzathine_penicillin_G)_intramuscular_as_a_single_dose.Note:_This_is_the_extended-release_formulation_only_for_intramuscular_use.Pediatric_dose_(based_on_weight)Weight_Ã³27_kg:_Give_600,000_units_(benzathine_penicillin_G)_intramuscular_as_a_single_dose.Weight_>27_kg:_Give_1.2_million_units_(benzathine_penicillin_G)_intramuscular_as_a_single_dose.Note:_This_is_the_extended-release_formulation_only_for_intramuscular_use.For_penicillin-allergic_patientsAdult_dose_(choose_one_of_the_following)Clindamycin_300_mg_by_mouth_every_8_hours_for_10_daysCephalexin_500_mg_by_mouth_every_12_hours_for_10_daysPediatric_dose_(choose_one_of_the_following)Clindamycin:_Give_7_mg/kg/dose_by_mouth_every_8_hours_for_10_days_(maximum_dose:_300_mg).Cephalexin:_Give_20_mg/kg/dose_by_mouth_every_12_hours_for_10_days_(maximum_dose:_500_mg).Note:_We_do_not_recommend_cephalexin_if_the_allergic_reaction_to_penicillin_is_anaphylaxis_or_another_severe_allergic_reaction.Corticosteroids_(eg,_dexamethasone)_provide_symptomatic_relief_in_patients_with_group_A_?-hemolytic_Streptococcus_without_increasing_serious_adverse_events.Adults_6-10_mg_intravenous_as_a_one-time_doseChildren_0.6_mg/kg_by_mouth_as_a_one-time_dose_(maximum_single_dose:_10_mg)Children_should_remain_home_from_school_or_daycare_until_afebrile_for_24_hours.

Airway_management_(eg,_rapid_sequence_intubation_with_a_cuffed_endotracheal_tube)_may_be_required_in_cases_of_severe_bleeding.A_difficult_airway_should_be_anticipated,_and_airway_adjuncts_(bougie,_supraglottic_airway,_fiberoptic_laryngoscope,_multiple_suction_catheters,_and_surgical_airway_kit)_must_be_readily_available.Resuscitate_patients_in_hemorrhagic_shock_with_blood_products._Obtain_at_least_2_large-bore_intravenous_catheters_and_initiate_a_massive_transfusion_protocol_administering_warm_products_at_a_1:1:1_ratio_of_red_blood_cells_to_plasma_to_platelets._Intravenous_crystalloid_solution_can_be_used_while_waiting_for_blood_but_should_be_limited_in_order_to_prevent_hypothermia_and_dilution_of_coagulation_factors.Proper_illumination_(with_a_head_lamp,_a_laryngoscope_held_by_the_patient_or_assistant,_or_other_method)_is_key.Positioning:_Keep_the_patient_upright_to_reduce_the_risk_of_swallowed_or_aspirated_blood.Use_an_antiemetic_to_reduce_the_risk_of_vomiting:Ondansetron:_based_on_weightÃ³40_kg:_0.1_mg/kg_intravenous_(maximum_dose_4_mg)>40_kg:_4_mg_intravenousDose_may_be_repeated_if_needed.Hemorrhage_control_and_reassessmentUncooperative_patients_or_those_with_significant_bleeding_may_require_intubation_and_operative_management.PITFALLSIf_bleeding_has_stopped_or_is_minor_and_a_clot_is_visualized_in_the_operative_bed,_do_not_disrupt_the_clot.Patient_should_go_immediately_to_the_operating_room_for_definitive_management.Cooperative_patients_with_minor_bleeding_may_benefit_from_gargling_with_ice_water._If_this_approach_fails,_consider_cauterizing_the_site_of_bleeding_with_silver_nitrate_(with_caution,_as_excessive_cauterization_can_damage_underlying_structures).PEARLSFor_significant_bleeding:An_antiemetic_(eg,_ondansetron)_should_be_administered_to_minimize_vomiting_of_swallowed_blood.Attempt_direct_pressure_with_a_hemostatic_agent.Tranexamic_acid_500_mg_(5_mL_of_injectable_solution)_undiluted,_soaked_in_gauze_or_cotton_and_applied_directly_against_the_bleeding_site_using_Magill_forceps_for_10-30_minutes.If_tranexamic_acid_is_not_available_epinephrine_1_mg/mL_solution_can_be_used.Nebulized_medication,_eg,_nebulized_epinephrine_and/or_tranexamic_acid)_can_be_administered.Racemic_epinephrine_2.25%_0.25_mL_nebulized_orTranexamic_acidIf_Ã³25_kg,_give_250_mg_(2.5_mL_of_injectable_solution)_over_2-3_minutes_via_jet_nebulizer_every_6_hours_until_bleeding_cessation.If_>25_kg,_give_500_mg_(5_mL_of_injectable_solution)_over_2-3_minutes_via_jet_nebulizer_every_6_hours_until_bleeding_cessation.Intravenous_tranexamic_acid_may_be_given_in_addition_to_above.Tranexamic_acid_10_mg/kg_intravenous_over_10_minutes_every_8_hours_(maximum_dose_1000_mg).There_is_a_concern_that_intravenous_tranexamic_acid_may_not_reach_therapeutic_saliva_concentration_for_antifibrinolytic_effect.PERSPECTIVESWe_recommend_a_stepwise_approach_to_control_bleeding,_with_initial_direct_pressure,_then_nebulized_racemic_epinephrine_2.25%_0.25_mL,_immediately_followed_by_nebulized_tranexamic_acid,_and_if_needed_intravenous_tranexamic_acid.Desmopressin_(DDAVP)_may_be_considered_in_addition_to_above,_especially_in_children,_due_to_the_possibility_of_previously_undiagnosed_von_Willebrand_disease0.3_Ã¦g/kg_in_50_mL_0.9%_sodium_chloride_intravenous_infusion_over_20_to_30_minutes.Definitive_management_in_the_operating_room_may_be_required.
